#Summary1=(human1) The problems in organizations often stem from flawed systems rather than individuals, illustrating through GM and Toyota’s experiences that effective management focuses on collaborative support and system improvement, rather than blaming or punishing workers, to achieve success.

#Summary2=(claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022) In 1983, Toyota transformed GM's worst-performing plant in Fremont by introducing collaborative management practices that improved worker morale and productivity, demonstrating that systemic changes, rather than blaming individuals, can revolutionize organizational performance.

#Summary3=(gpt4o) Aaron Swartz's article "Fix the Machine, Not the Person" highlights the successful transformation of a dysfunctional General Motors plant when Toyota introduced collaborative management practices, emphasizing that organizational systems, not individuals, often need fixing to achieve desired outcomes effectively.

#Summary4=(Meta-Llama-3-8B-Instruct) Academics and industry experts argue that the problem with the General Motors Fremont plant's poor performance was not the workers, but the system, and that by changing the system, workers can be motivated and produce high-quality results.

#Summary5=(Qwen2.5-7B-Instruct) A poorly managed General Motors plant in Fremont transformed into one of the best in the US after adopting Toyota's collaborative management techniques, demonstrating that systemic changes rather than individual worker behavior improvements are key to organizational success.
#Text=Fix the Machine , Not the Person ( Swartz )
#Text=By Aaron Swartz
#Text=#systemanalysis , #proposal , #technology , #automotiveindustry , #logos , #research , #sharedvalues #cognitivebias
#Text=“ Photo ” is in the Public Domain , CC0
#Text=This post is part seven of the series Raw Nerve .
#Text=The General Motors plant in Fremont was a disaster .
#Text=“ Everything was a fight , ” the head of the union admits .
#Text=“ They spent more time on grievances and on things like that than they did on producing cars .
#Text=They had strikes all the time .
#Text=It was just chaos constantly . ...
#Text=It was considered the worst workforce in the automobile industry in the United States . ”
#Text=“ One of the expressions was , you can buy anything you want in the GM plant in Fremont , ” adds Jeffrey Liker , a professor who studied the plant .
#Text=“ If you want sex , if you want drugs , if you want alcohol , it 's there .
#Text=During breaks , during lunch time , if you want to gamble illegally — any illegal activity was available for the asking within that plant . ”
#Text=Absenteeism was so bad that some mornings they did n’t have enough employees to start the assembly line ; they had to go across the street and drag people out of the bar .

#Text=When management tried to punish workers , workers tried to punish them right back : scratching cars , loosening parts in hard - to - reach places , filing union grievances , sometimes even building cars unsafely .
#Text=It was war .
#Text=In 1982 , GM finally closed the plant .

#Text=But the very next year , when Toyota was planning to start its first plant in the US , it decided to partner with GM to reopen it , hiring back the same old disastrous workers into the very same jobs .
#Text=And so began the most fascinating experiment in management history .
#Text=Toyota flew this rowdy crew to Japan , to see an entirely different way of working : The Toyota Way .
#Text=At Toyota , labor and management considered themselves on the same team ; when workers got stuck , managers did n’t yell at them , but asked how they could help and solicited suggestions .
#Text=It was a revelation .

#Text=“ You had union workers — grizzled old folks that had worked on the plant floor for 30 years , and they were hugging their Japanese counterparts , just absolutely in tears , ” recalls their Toyota trainer .

#Text=“ And it might sound flowery to say 25 years later , but they had had such a powerful emotional experience of learning a new way of working , a way that people could actually work together collaboratively — as a team .
#Text=Three months after they got back to the US and reopened the plant , everything had changed .
#Text=Grievances and absenteeism fell away and workers started saying they actually enjoyed coming to work .
#Text=The Fremont factory , once one of the worst in the US , had skyrocketed to become the best .
#Text=The cars they made got near - perfect quality ratings .
#Text=And the cost to make them had plummeted .
#Text=It was n’t the workers who were the problem ; it was the system .
#Text=An organization is not just a pile of people , it 's also a set of structures .
#Text=It 's almost like a machine made of men and women .
#Text=Think of an assembly line .
#Text=If you just took a bunch of people and threw them in a warehouse with a bunch of car parts and a manual , it ’d probably be a disaster .
#Text=Instead , a careful structure has been built : car parts roll down on a conveyor belt , each worker does one step of the process , everything is carefully designed and routinized .
#Text=Order out of chaos .
#Text=And when the system is n’t working , it does n’t make sense to just yell at the people in it — any more than you ’d try to fix a machine by yelling at the gears .
#Text=True , sometimes you have the wrong gears and need to replace them , but more often you ’re just using them in the wrong way .
#Text=When there ’s a problem , you should n’t get angry with the gears — you should fix the machine .
#Text=If you have goals in life , you ’re probably going to need some sort of organization .
#Text=Even if it ’s an organization of just you , it ’s still helpful to think of it as a kind of machine .
#Text=You do n’t need to do every part of the process yourself — you just need to set up the machine so that the right outcomes happen .
#Text=For example , let ’s say you want to build a treehouse in the backyard .
#Text=You ’re great at sawing and hammering , but architecture is not your forte .
#Text=You build and build , but the treehouses keep falling down .
#Text=Sure , you can try to get better at architecture , develop a better design , but you can also step back , look at the machine as a whole , and decide to fire yourself as the architect .
#Text=Instead , you find a friend who loves that sort of thing to design the treehouse for you and you stick to actually building it .
#Text=After all , your goal was to build a treehouse whose design you like — does it really matter whether you ’re the one who actually designed it ?
#Text=Or let ’s say you really want to get in shape , but never remember to exercise .
#Text=You can keep beating yourself up for your forgetfulness , or you can put a system in place .
#Text=Maybe you have your roommate check to see that you exercise before you leave your house in the morning or you set a regular time to consistently go to the gym together .
#Text=Life is n’t a high school exam ; you do n’t have to solve your problems on your own .

#Text=In 1967 , Edward Jones and Victor Harris gathered a group of college students and asked them to judge another student ’s exam ( the student was a fictional character , but let ’s call him Jim ) .
#Text=The exam always had one question , asking Jim to write an essay on Fidel Castro “ as if [ he ] were giving the opening statement in a debate . ”
